dict.string: As the youngest of five children in her family, she was born in 1867 in Warsaw, in the Russian partition of Poland.
Working with her husband, she discovered two different elements, polonium and radium in the same year.
In her early research with uranium, she showed that atoms were divisible, which led to the creation of atomic physics.
Instead of wearing a bridal grown, she wore a dark blue dress, which served her for many years as a laboratory outfit.
She died of aplastic anemia due to prolonged exposure to radiation, but she never realized the health risks of her work.
She was inspired by her father, a physics teacher who allowed his children to play with his lab equipment at home.
Her husband Pierre researched magnetism, but a contemporary quipped that his greatest discovery was Marie.
To afford university tuition and living expense, she studied during the day and worked as a tutor in the evening.
As a woman, she was barred from higher education in her native country and moved to Paris to earn her doctorate.
Her work-related papers are still radioactive, and those who wish to consult them must wear protective clothing.
